thread.title: Incoming Cybersecurity Adviser Giuliani Under Fire For Security Gaps On His Company Website
thread.title_full: Incoming Cybersecurity Adviser Giuliani Under Fire For Security Gaps On His Company Website

author: Andrew Kerr
title: Incoming Cybersecurity Adviser Giuliani Under Fire For Security Gaps On His Company Website
text:
Incoming Cybersecurity Adviser Giuliani Under Fire For Security Gaps On His Company Website "... it barely even qualifies ..." Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print   
Former New York City mayor Rudy Giuliani had a rude awakening Thursday, shortly after being named an informal adviser on cybersecurity to President-elect Donald Trump. 
Trump’s transition team touted Giuliani’s 16 years of providing security solutions to the private sector through his consulting firm Giuliani Partners. 
However, upon review of Giuliani ‘s company website, independent cybersecurity experts concluded that the former mayor had failed to safeguard his company’s website with even the most basic security measures.   Reports Claim Trump Has Decided On ‘Mold-Breaking Pick’ For Secretary Of State 
Giuliani’s website, GiulianiSecurity.com, crashed several times Thursday, and was still down as of late Friday afternoon, Eastern time. 
Experts say the most glaring security flaw was the outdated version of Joomla! utilized on Giuliani’s website. More than a dozen security vulnerabilities have been identified in the four-year-old version of the free content management system. 
Dan Tenter, founder of the security firm Phobos Group, said no apparent effort was made to safeguard the site from hackers.   
Tenter said he was able to pull “read me” files from Giuliani’s website that provided pertinent information hackers could use to compromise the website. 
“This is really, really, really basic — it barely even qualifies as security,” he told CNBC . “Those files give you all the information you need to do nefarious things.” 
Qualys SSL Labs, a free online service that performs analysis on the security configuration of any public website, gave Giuliani’s website an “F” security rating.
